												One of the first things I noticed about Rogue Warrior was how good the music is. In a lot of games I end up turning off the music because it’s too depressing or repetitive. The music in this game is awesome, its genuinely cool and adds to the fun. Mickey Rourke did the voice acting, for the main character here, who’s name is Rourke. His dialogue and performance are hilarious. Even though he literally sounds, like he’s not bothered on some of the parts between levels. I really enjoy when games don’t take things too seriously and with Rogue Warrior this is definitely the case.I had to tweak things a little bit, so that I could play it, at a smooth 60FPS with no stuttering. It’s easy to find some information on this with a quick search. Having made these basic changes the game runs really well for me (my specs are on my profile). Rourke's 'ultimate badass' attitude is ridiculous in the most entertaining way. His dialogue is hilariously over the top and the violence is taken to a weird level. Even though it's poorly made, even for 2009 (it looks like a PS2 remaster), this somehow also adds to the 'so bad, it's good' charm of the game. The only thing that’s a bit annoying is the poor hit detection but it works ‘okay’ enough to still be fun. I’m also assuming  that this game was not full price on consoles back in 2009 because it is crazy short. This is fine for a cheap silly game on Steam but just know that this game is basic in it’s gameplay mechanics and over very quickly. It’s a fairly challenging game though, for what it is, if you’re not careful you will die a lot (even on the standard difficulty). In my opinion, some games try to be too dramatic and this can end up ruining the fun. Rogue Warrior doesn’t have that problem, at all. It's a blast and It captures something I love about videogames. Which is when the fantastically crap and ridiculous ends up being surreal and fun.P.S: Rourke climbs ladders like a ♥♥♥♥ing machine!!

												2008 was Bethesda's year of antithesis, due to the publication of fallout 3, the greatest game of all time, and Rebellion's Rogue Warrior, based on the american special forces legend, Richard "♥♥♥♥♥♥quot; Marcinko and although the premise is good, the game itself is a big piece of crap!Seriously, the best way to describe Rogue Warrior is you go to a concert starring Rise Against, Metallica and Foo Fighters (Nice presentation), but Tim, James and Dave got all sick and cancelled at the moment (starting to dissapoint pretty badly) and so, to substitute, Justin Bieber, One Direction and Lady Gaga appeared (before it's over, 95% of the people either left or killed themselves).Anyways, starting with the story, there is none. It's just a bunch of missions and thats it (well, the missions are related, but a "found these papers, going to the location mentioned in these papers to stop the enemies!" doesn't really count as a story to me...).Moving to the graphics, they are very bad,  I mean, i've seen PS2 and older PC games from like 2005 or 06 that look better than this♥♥♥♥♥♥Going to the gameplay: There is a cover system! Rarity in FPS's these days, but it's over simplistic and it feels clunky as hell! I hoped it would be like Rainbow Six:Vegas 2 which was fine, perhaps even good...but nope! Rogue Warrior has you stick to cover pressing one button and thats it.Gunplay is horrendous, the guns feel absolutely terrible, and you might want to just stick to your silenced pistol and the melee moves, oh yeah! This game has a "press E to win" prompt btw and if you're skilled enough, you can go through 90% of the whole game just by getting up close and personal to the enemies and pressing E (you are not vulnerable during the animation, which is even easier!) the other 10% is just dull sniping the rest of the unreachable enemies with the knife. Don't get me wrong, the melee "cutscenes" aren't bad, teh animation are quite good, but after the 3rd one, it gets repetitive and stupid.Moving to Multiplayer! It completely sucks! It's over simplistic, just kill and thats it! Very old school styled (pick up the weapons you find on the ground or hidden places, there aren't classes or anything like that, like i said, very simplistic and boring), you don't gain experience nor anything, you dont get rewarded for doing good or punished for sucking and that makes it kind of...boring after 10 minutes. Also, noone is playing the Multiplayer of this game, it only has 850 game Hub contributions, so...yeah...it's THAT popular...With sucky multiplayer, bad graphicss, dull and exhausting gameplay and a 3 hour long campaign (no joke!) Rogue Warrior just deserves a 1/10, miserable disappointment. And Rebellion that does great games! I got it for 2,49 € and it still feels overpriced! BTW, the game reeks of a pretty bad console port! Don't buy this, please! Save your 2€ and go buy a sandwich, it lasts longer than this game!

THE LOWDOWN:Rogue Warrior is an old-skool corridor shooter with limited cover mechanics and minor stealth elements.  Your objective is to one-man Rambo; an eight mission campaign, set in the Peoples Republic of North Korea.  Choose to kill by stealth but be seen and its time for gun-toting action.  The campaign is single-player but it has a multi-player arena style deathmatch with a few maps.  THE GOOD:+ Simple gameplay. Other than picking up weapons/ammo, there is little to interact with.+ Fast-paced action.+ Cheesy voice-over from Mickey Rouke.  Some great one-liners.  Sounds like it was made while sitting on the crapper!+ Who doesnt like taking on PRK enemies!? ^^+ The music is old-skool tacky, gradually getting boom-tastic at the end.  Perfect for this game!+ Nice range of achievements which are fairly fast to gain.  + On sale its very cheap.THE BAD:- Its very short.  Too short!- Cliche backstory.  But who doesnt like them right!?- Scripted levels are purely linear.- Rudimentary graphics give it a minimalistic ambience.  Well its an old game.- Mostly similar enemies that just carry different firearms.- Enemies attack in waves but even on Elite difficulty numbers are very low.- Some MP achievements require other players.  At least four.  This is a problem to get them even if there are a few die-hards on the discussion boards.- Very limited replayability.  Everything is virtually the same the second time around.- No matter what weapons you pick up in the previous chapter, they are reset at the start of the next one.AND THE ORDINARY:* Gameplay is fairly one-dimensional apart from minor stealth and cover mechanics.* A.I is adequate but nothing to write home about.* Short 8 mission campaign.* 3 difficulty levels.  Just go to elite.  Its really not that difficult!* Lite in-game story-driven cutscenes.* Arena based PvP multiplayer. If youre into that sort of thing.  Unfortunately all but dead.* Carry 2 weapons but can choose from 13 different weapons (pistols, shotguns, SMGs, assault rifle, sniper rifle, LMG and a grenade-launcer.  Unfortunately none are realistically modelled or very satisfying to use.* Decent K/M controls.  Unbidden tendency for weapon-switching to occur with mouse-wheel.* You will need to complete the game three times; once at each difficulty to get 100%.VERDICT:Rogue Warrior is frankly terrible!  Its a mediocre FPS.  Ultimately limited by its age its levels are designed to be completely linear.  Gameplay decisions mostly fall as to whether to kill with silent takedowns or alert enemies and blast them with whatever weapons you have to hand.  However Its enjoyable in a minimalistic kind of way.  Just dont expect anything like a modern-day shooter or a AAA title and you may find enough to saite your appetite.  It will appeal to fans of brainless, easy to beat FPS.  Definitely one of the 'Its so bad, its good!'  One to miss unless you love old-skool beer and pretzel-style shooters or if you are a sucker for punishment!EDIT:- After spending 4hrs trying to get 8 ppl to connect to a single host I can tell you this game has the worst MP facility of any PC game I have ever played and should be avoided at all cost, just for that alone.  I still recommend the game but only for a cheesy SP experience, dont bother thinking about the MP achievements.  They are nigh on impossible to get because you cant even get 4 ppl to consistently connect in a 2v2 game.  Abysmal.

												Bethesda markets Rogue Warrior as a “character-driven first person shooter”, which is stretching the definition of character slightly. The game takes place in 1986, where North Koreans and Russians are doing sinister weapons research. This calls for our hero called♥♥♥♥♥♥ who is ready to stop them, armed with an enormous amount of lovely one-liners like “♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥breath commie ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s”. It’s like poetry.This game is only slightly better than the very worst a game can be. The music sounds like it’s from a free music library, but probably isn’t, while the graphics and audio also only meet the quality standard of free template assets. You know you’re in trouble when something as simple as “walking forward” feels bad. To the game’s credit, it only took me 109 minutes to complete. I was in the mood to play something that was total♥♥♥♥♥♥ and it certainly delivered exactly what I was hoping for. If you’re going to make a garbage game, this is the level you should aspire to hit at a minimum. I wasn’t bored by it, and it had the decency to end early. It also didn’t feel like some crap thrown together at random. They tried to make something coherent here, something that resembled a real game. But they didn’t have the means, talent or maybe even the will to make that happen. There’s a reason this game is consistently brought up as a legendary piece of crap 7 years after it came out, while thousands of other bad games are forgotten. It’s hard to put my finger on just what makes this memorable, but it’s the “right” kind of bad to leave an impression, which many mediocre games don’t. Maybe it’s simply the one-liners.

Posted: September 25, 2015
												Imagine that a writer and a composer watched The Rock and were so inspired by Michael Bay's brilliant explosions and Hans Zimmer's catchy riffs that they decided to make a game inspired by that hit 90's movie. Except this time the protagonists are fighting foreign communists instead of domestic terrorists. They nail the superficial aspects of the style while forgetting to include any substance. That's Rogue Warrior.It's a brash, simple, and pointedly racist FPS with little that's notable about it other than the repetitive and profane one-liners voiced by Mickey Rourke. He is by far the best choice possible to pull this off, but how they convinced him to take the job I have no idea. Maybe he didn't see the script ahead of time. Or maybe that's where all the budget went.The strangest thing to me is that the game claims to be "character-driven" in its description while actually being the farthest thing from it. There's more character development in an alphabet book.You've only got a couple of tired weapons to choose from and a couple of dumb enemies to fight. So gameplay-wise it's even below par for standard FPS fare. Throw in an awkward cover system that forces you into third-person mode and that's all you need to know about the mechanics.The game is also terribly short. My first playthrough on the highest difficulty was just north of three hours. My second run on normal was just about an hour and a half. And my final go on easy was under an hour. There's just not much to this game in any dimension.And yet...there might be a place for it in your library. A fast, not-challenging run through of an FPS you've never played before can be a fun experience. It can scratch a certain kind of itch. If you've already beaten every Call of Duty and Battlefield there is then there might not be many other places you could look than Rogue Warrior. But it's not fundamentally good. It's just there.

												One of the worst games I have played in a long time. It is only 2 hours long, which actually I could say as bad as it is, this is a positive thing. It is extremely generic, and reminds me strongly of a few other games I can think of that are just like it: Damnation, Dark Sector, and Velvet Assassin. The slow jam song at the end with Rourke's lines all edited together to rhyme was pretty funny though.Graphics look like 2005, not 2009, ai is really bad, and weapons firing sounds like kids toys. The music is extremely generic, the levels are 100% linear, and are void of any possible interaction besides hit E to open a door or plant a bomb. The stealth is as basic as it can possibly get. Crouch down and hit E to stealth kill, or just sprint to an enemy and do it. Most of the time it only lets you stealth kill a few guys then the rest of the level is designed to be bad generic gunplay.Really bad game but still better than a lot of other similar generic games like the ones I mentioned. It would be worth buying over those games if it wasn't only 2 hours long, but is still only barely a 4/10 game either way.

												★½ out of four.Unfortunately, it is actually technical problems that most notably hinder this game. Completing it in three hours and two sittings, my technical experience was different both times.It seems stuttering may be a problem for some configurations; I never experienced this. The first sitting the game would occasionally freeze or freeze and show my desktop and then flicker back to the game. This got very frequent and bothersome after a time. The second sitting only had this a few times, but now there was consistent screen tearing. However, the tearing was not an egregious variety -- smooth and fleeting for what it was. It seems prospective players are taking a gamble on how the game will actually run for them.FOV seems non-adjustable, but it was managable. Another massive problem was aim-down-sights on probably a bit over half of the guns is broken such that the point the bullets actually hit is down into the model of the gun itself.If you need to do some♥♥♥♥♥♥shooter, this can be cheaper and leaner than alternatives. There are no collectables, so one can enjoy going through the linear game-path. Story gets a touch less coherent at the end. There is swearing, but I would have preferred more or more additional variations at least. There are a few tracks, so sometimes you're left in the quiet, but at least the tracks have a beat to them. The broadly noted Credits track is great and a great reward, but you can always select it directly from the main menu if you must. Difficulty achievements don't stack, so I'd run on Normal and watch for standing near explosives.

												Review of Rogue Warrior:Brief History: Rogue warriow is based off a novel (or novel series) about Richard ♥♥♥♥♥♥ Marcinco, a US Navy SEAL. The books, including an autobiography, and several spinoff fiction books. The autobiography calls him a "death defying" soldier, who was in the United States's SEAL Team Six, an incredibly impressive feat.Game Summary: In this game, you control a profanity-spewing♥♥♥♥♥♥(as the game wants him to be called) Marcinko, murder hordes of communists in hilarious and over-the-top ways. You have to blow a lot of stuff up, including submarines and missles (yes, that is the entire plot). This game takes itself too seriously (like most modern shooters, Battlefield and Call of Duty to name a few), and seems like it tries too hard to earn it's M rating. Many times per mission, Marcinko spouts profanity; including every couple of hallways, every time he is hit, or just every like he says in general. The takedown cutscenes try to be brutal, but fail. The game has glitches, such as all enemies knowing where you are and enemies being able to shoot through cover, and all glitches work against you. There is one glitch where, sometimes, your guns will have no recoil while in cover, but that was all I could find. This game is incredibly short, with two hours of main campaign time. This game has lots of achievments, but sadly you cannot get them all due to some needing multiplayer (which no one plays). This game is actually tremendously funny, mostly because of lines like, "The wind was so cold, it could freeze the balls off a f**king polar bear" and "F**k! F**k you, you f**king ametuer peices of s**t" and most of all, "Suck my balls, my giant, hairy, big f**king balls, wrap 'em around your neck you c**k-sucking motherf**kers!"I apologize for that.Upsides:This game is one of the funniest you will play in a long time.Marcinko's dialouge keeps the "flow of gameplay" consistant.This game has a good soundtrack.The game is surprisingly fun.Average shooter.Stealth kind of works a bit.Has a cover system that would be fantastic if improved on.Good mix of FPS and TPS (First Person and Third Person)Has the best end credits theme of all time, no joke.Downsides:Game is incredibly glitchy.Game has ways of killing you out of nowhere.Some of Marcinko's lines make you cringe. (Such as, "Fondle my hairy nuts")Game is WAY too short, it feels like a Call of duty: Modern Warfare DLC.Cover system breaks a bit.Random difficulty spikes. (One minute you kill twenty enemies, no problem. Then one guy pins/kills you a bunch)Difficulty levels have almost no difference.Game takes itself too seriously.Multiplayer mode.Nobody plays multiplayer mode.Most guns feel the same.No jumping.No melee attack, you get a cutscene.Cutscenes usually make no sense.Reload animation doesn't match up with actual reload.OVERALL:3/10 (Very bad)Last comments:This is one of those games that is so bad, it's good. It is a bad game, but it makes for two-three hours of intense laughter. I reccomend this game to those who want a more casual shooter that supplies fun in short bursts.Price Tag: $10.00What it is Worth: $3.00What I Paid: $5.00What I Would Pay: $5.00

												This is really not a very good FPS game. The level design is poor, the story is absurd, and the main character uses four letter words at the rate of one every two seconds. Perhaps the strangest game play element is the stealth move. You can sneak up on an opponent and use the stelth move to kill them. However, you can also (if you run fast enough) rush an enemy firing their weapon in your face, use the stelth move, and kill them with a knife. I have gone through entire levels just rushing enemies with my knife and never firing a shot. Apparently, when running in stealth mode  you are immune from bullet damage.Playing more than ten minutes of this game (and you can "beat" the game in less than two hours), requires a strong stomach. The only bright spot is that I can use this game in my Game Design class as a bad example of how not to do an FPS game.

												Wow. Just wow. This game ought to serve as a crash course on how not to design and execute a game. A literal crash course because I beat it in less than two hours. I would've beaten it faster if I didn't die because of so much random♥♥♥♥♥♥exploding all over the place.Let me go over all the key points that every game developer should take note of in this game, and look not to do:- It took me less than two hours to beat it. Seriously. - There was no option to adjust resolution or lighting quality. In fact, there's exactly four options on the video menu.- Thank god they allowed me to turn off the motion blur, because it's so ♥♥♥♥ing intense that it makes me nauseous just thinking about it, and I'm usually a fan of motion blur in games.- There's no vsync whatsoever, and the game has screen tears like a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥- The lighting quality is so inconsistent that it makes my head hurt. Some areas are completely unlit and others are really well lit.- The fire effects look pretty similar to a 90's FPS. They look atrocious.- There's grenade indicators in this game, but you're the only person that can throw grenades (WTF)- There's no subtitles. Which as I point out later, is both a good thing and a bad thing.- There's no other option besides English to play this game in.- Let's talk about controls...for starters, you can't even access half the controls without using a controller, as the scroll menu can't be scrolled down using either the mouse or the keyboard..you'll need a controller to even do that.- During the game, I was told to "pull back on the left stick in order to move away from cover" when I was using mouse and keyboard.- The horizontal and vertical sensitivity for the mouse aren't consistent. The vertical sensitivity is about half as sensitive as the horizontal sensitivity, if not less.- The horizontal and forward/backward movement isn't consistent either. Once again, you move almost 2x as fast when moving sideways or backwards (?!) than you do moving forwards. Wat.- Iron sights are bound to the space bar by default, and the grenade key is bound to the right mouse button. Did anyone bother to play this game on PC? Seriously..- There's only two weapons in the game, yet there's three different binds to switch weapons, all of which do the same thing. The hell?- Speaking of weapons, there's a grand total of 8 of them in the actual game, and NPCs only ever use and drop 3 of them. Every weapon is obtainable in every mission.- There's a huge amount of ammo in the game, so don't worry about running out of it.- Can one-hit-kill everything by walking up to it and pressing F.- NPCs are completely bugged, their AI is totally ♥♥♥♥ed up beyond belief.- Voice acting quality is legitimately terrible, everyone sounds like they're talking through a cardboard tube. THE END.- There's three types of enemies in this game: Asian Commies, Russian Commies, and Russian Commies wearing helmets- Each mission: kill a few guys stealthily, suddenly you can't kill everyone stealthily so you have to go loud, and then you plant bombs on things and win. 												This is really not a very good FPS game. The level design is poor, the story is absurd, and the main character uses four letter words at the rate of one every two seconds. The main character comes across as so disagreeable you find yourself running him into a fire fight just to get him killed. Not a good way to make the player associate with their game character.The level design is bad and the graphics are poor for even 2009. The enemy AI is brain-dead. Perhaps the strangest game play element is the stealth move. You can sneak up on an opponent and use the stelth move to kill them. However, you can also (if you run fast enough) rush an enemy firing their weapon in your face, use the stelth move, and kill them with a knife. I have gone through entire levels just rushing enemies with my knife and never firing a shot. Apparently, when running in stealth mode  you are immune from bullet damage.Playing more than ten minutes of this game (and you can "beat" the game in less than two hours), requires a strong stomach. The only bright spot is that I can use this game in my Game Design class as a bad example of how not to do an FPS game.
